title: 113_hr2569
content: The Act is titled the "Upper Missisquoi and Trout Wild and Scenic Rivers Act" and designates specific river segments as wild and scenic. The "Upper Missisquoi and Trout Wild and Scenic Rivers Act" designates segments of the Missisquoi River and Trout River in Vermont as recreational rivers, administered by the Secretary of the Interior. This includes specific segments of the Missisquoi River from Lowell/Westfield to the Canadian border, excluding certain hydroelectric facilities, and the Trout River for a total of 45.1 miles. The Trout River segment designated for recreational use spans 11 miles from Montgomery to East Berkshire where it meets the Missisquoi River. SEC. 3. MANAGEMENT. The river segments designated by paragraph (208) of section 3(a) of the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act shall be managed in accordance with the Upper Missisquoi and Trout Rivers Management Plan and any amendments approved by the Committee. The management plan finalized in March 2013, and any amendments, satisfy the requirements for a comprehensive management plan under the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act. The Secretary may coordinate management responsibilities with the Committee and enter into cooperative agreements for the protection and enhancement of designated river segments. The Wild and Scenic Rivers Act allows for cooperative agreements with Vermont, municipalities, and planning organizations consistent with the management plan. These agreements may include financial assistance from the United States. The designation of river segments does not affect existing hydroelectric facilities. The Wild and Scenic Rivers Act allows cooperative agreements with Vermont, municipalities, and planning organizations for financial assistance. It does not restrict the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission from licensing or making changes to existing hydroelectric projects. Hydropower proceedings' resource protection measures are not considered project works under this Act. (e) Land Management.-- Zoning ordinances in Vermont towns along designated river segments satisfy Wild and Scenic Rivers Act standards. Secretary authorized for land acquisitions. The Secretary is authorized to acquire land for designated river segments under the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act through donation or exchange, with additional criteria in the management plan. Condemnation of land within these segments is prohibited, and written consent of the owner is required for inclusion of private or non-Federal public property. The Missisquoi and Trout Rivers shall not be part of the National Park System or subject to its regulations. No buffer zones will be created outside designated river segment boundaries. The management of activities or uses outside designated river segments will not be determined by information heard, detected, or observed within those segments. The House of Representatives passed the document on September 15, 2014, as attested by Karen L. Haas, Clerk.
